title: Is Kant's categorical imperative valid? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s a little weak—never treat others as MERE means but always as self-determining beings. Always get consent for the ways you treat them. More likely you should never treat people as means/tools/objects at all. Dehumanization in doing so seems unavoidable. (Kantians like Rawls have noted this.) The other part of the CI about being able to rationally universalize any intent? Well, in the realm of universal principles, that’s a fine foundation. But then we need many contextual principles as well—medium-sized and to the point of particular situations. Kant’s “kingdom of ends” model makes it look like the CI is a decision-making principle. Luckily he notes that it’s only for ruling out certain intents as morally irrational. It’s a good guard against a certain kind of inconsistency, focusing on how to treat each other as sentient beings per se. But there are endless ways we should treat each other affirmatively in different social roles, in the roles of particular societies, groups, often where so-called “special responsibilities” apply. But they are not “special.” These are front-row responsibility. The CI deals with way in the background ones, fundamental but also minimal ones. At least that’s how I remember it, not having the text in front of me right now as I should.

Perhaps I’m mistaken, but I take Kant’s Categorical Imperative to mean the same thing as Nietzsche’s offering of the Eternal Return—a basis for judging the morality of an action without involving a divine moral authority. Both are clarion calls to consider the bigger picture of the consequences of one’s actions. In Kant’s case, if you decide that it’s okay to cheat, you have just given dispensation to everyone else to cheat you should they so choose, as well; in other words, whatsoever a man soweth, so also shall he reap. In Nietzsche’s case, your choice to cheat—along with its consequences—will repeat endlessly, like Groundhog Day; in other words, what goes around, comes around…again and again and again. Both are valid definitions of a Godless Moral Compass.
